subject: Serious questions tonight about the safety of a popular diabetes drug. That's coming up on the CBS Evening News with Katie Couric.

QUOTE OF THE DAY"I have such poor vision I can 
      date anybody." - Garry Shandling 

DID YOU KNOW?Australians consume 60% more coffee than 
      tea, a sixfold increase since 1940. 

TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWSHere is an early preview of what we 
      are planning for tonight's CBS EVENING NEWS from Anchor and Managing 
      Editor, Katie Couric... Hi everyone, A 
      prescription drug that's been taken by more than 6 million people has been 
      linked to a significantly higher risk of heart attack - and even death. 
      Wyatt Andrews will report on Avandia, and our medical correspondent 
      Dr. Jon LaPook will explain what this news means to families who 
      deal with type 2 diabetes. In other medical news, a new pill is 
      promising birth control with a boost. It could be relief for women from 
      the pains and inconveniences of their menstrual cycles. It is due to debut 
      tomorrow but, as Michelle Miller will report, its long-term safety 
      isn't clear. Gas prices have broken the record for high prices set 
      during the energy crisis of the early 1980s - when they are adjusted for 
      inflation - until now. Anthony Mason will report on how tight 
      refinery capacity is the latest cause of high prices at the pump, and 
      Byron Pitts will have the story of how gasoline costs are affecting 
      consumers. Tension in the Middle East can be another factor in 
      high gas prices and over the past two days violent urban warfare has 
      erupted in Lebanon. Intense fighting between Lebanese troops and Islamic 
      militants suspected of having ties to al Qaeda has killed dozens of 
      people. Mark Phillips will have the story. Some great 
      citizens of the country are being lauded for their valor in the wake of 
      Hurricane Katrina. Today one relatively unknown name is being added to the 
      list of John F. Kennedy "Profile in Courage Award" recipients, which 
      includes the likes of Kofi Annan and Gerald Ford. Her name is Doris 
      Voitier. Haven't heard of her? Correspondent Kelly Cobiella will 
      introduce you to this special woman tonight. I hope you'll 
      join us. Katie For more information on these 
      stories, please click on the following links: Diabetes Drug 
      Tied To Heart Risk In Study Click Here Lebanon's Fight With 
      Militants Heats Up Click Here And here's a look at 
      one of the stories we're working on for Tuesday's broadcast:
The City of Brotherly Love... We'll take you there when we 
      broadcast live from Philadelphia, Tuesday, on the CBS Evening 
      News. If you would like more 
      information on the broadcast, please click on the following address and 
      e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com 

TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANDave sits down with Republican Presidential 
      Candidate Rudolph Giuliani AND the inventor of the "Cra-Z-Boy Jet 
      Recliner" Mike West. Plus, musical guests Jesus & Mary Chain! 

TUESDAY
MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOWHarry 
      Smith, Hannah Storm, Julie Chen, and Russ 
      Mitchell anchor THE EARLY SHOW from New York. Dave 
      Price will bring us the weather. Along with the top news of 
      the day, we will also have the following stories: HAPPILY 
      EVER AFTER, PART 2: Remember your childhood crush, the schoolmate you 
      thought you'd marry someday? Chances are you've lost touch ages ago. Not 
      so for Darwin Hobbs... Tuesday morning we continue our week-long look at 
      true-life romantic couples in our series Happily Ever After. Darwin 
      of Grayson, Georgia, was so sure he'd marry his ten-year-old friend Traci 
      McCloud, he made sure everyone at school knew it. Nearly thirty years 
      later, they are together, living Happily Ever After. Through 
      hardships and struggles, they have stayed best friends. We'll hear their 
      story of love Tuesday morning. THE REAGAN DIARIES: The late 
      President Ronald Reagan was known as the great communicator. And now we 
      get to see why... On Monday, visitors to the Reagan Library lined up to be 
      the first to buy a new book made up of personal entries he kept almost 
      every day during his eight years in office. It is a very revealing account 
      of his presidency and his relationships with wife Nancy, his kids and the 
      American people.The book is called The Reagan Diaries and Spielas 
      Brinkley, CBS News Historian, is the book's editor. He will join us 
      from the Reagan Library in Simi Valley, California. TOM SELLECK 
      ON JESSE STONE: SEA CHANGE: Actor Tom Selleck is a man who needs no 
      introduction - except to say that the fourth installment of his popular 
      television movie series Jesse Stone, airs Tuesday on CBS. In 
      Jesse Stone: Sea Change, the popular small town police chief, tired 
      of writing tickets and still longing for his ex-wife and a bottle of 
      scotch, reopens a twelve year old cold case...hoping to give the unsolved 
      murder investigation, and even more so his life, a jump start. Tom Selleck 
      will join us Tuesday morning. KEOGHAN'S HEROES: The 
      Amazing Race may be taking the summer off, but host Phil Keoghan is 
      not. He is on assignment for THE EARLY SHOW, flying about 
      the country in a small plane, looking for great characters with 
      interesting stories. The first episode takes Phil to the Big Island of 
      Hawaii, where he met the heroes of hula. We'll have the story Tuesday 
      morning. SIMPLE SOLUTIONS: BOATING SAFETY: This is national 
      safe boating week--and this holiday weekend, more people than ever will be 
      hitting the water. But every year, boating accidents injure and kill 
      thousands of people. So how do you stay safe on the water? EARLY 
      SHOW Consumer Correspondent Susan Koeppen will join us from 
      Chelsea Piers in New York to talk about how to make boating both fun and 
      safe this summer. If you would like more information on any of 
      these stories or the broadcast, please click on the following address and 
      e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
